data.event: The 2010 census reported that the town had a total population of 6,786.

The compact town center, where 3,885 people resided at the 2010 census, is defined by the U.S. Census Bureau as the Farmington census-designated place and is located at the junction of New Hampshire routes 75 and 153.

event.title: 1721 the Colonial Assembly in Portsmouth approved

data.event: To stop the raids, in 1721 the Colonial Assembly in Portsmouth approved construction of a fort at the foot of the lake, with a soldiers' road built from Dover to supply it.

event.title: 1722, Bay Road was surveyed and completed

data.event: In 1722, Bay Road was surveyed and completed.
The settlement began as the Northwest Parish of Rochester, which was chartered in 1722.
The last Indian attack in the general region occurred in 1748, but by 1749, Native Americans had disappeared from warfare and disease.
The last Indian attack in the general region occurred in 1748, but by 1749, Native Americans had disappeared from warfare and disease.
Sawmills cut the abundant timber, and the first frame house at the village was built in 1782.
In 1790, Jonas March from Portsmouth established a store, behind which teamsters unloaded on his dock the lumber he traded.
The area became known as March's Dock, Farmington Dock, and finally just The Dock.
